prior_works.title: Clusterless decoding of position from multiunit activity using a marked point process filter
prior_works.authors: Deng X.; Liu D. F.; Kay K.; Frank L. M.; Eden U. T.
prior_works.role: Foundational clusterless decoding framework using marked point-process models and Gaussian-mixture mark distributions.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Directly informed the paper’s core idea of modeling the distribution of unsorted spike features with a mixture of Gaussians to decode behavior while marginalizing spike-identity uncertainty.

prior_works.title: Bayesian decoding using unsorted spikes in the rat hippocampus
prior_works.authors: Kloosterman F. E.; Layton S. P.; Chen Z.; Wilson M. A.
prior_works.role: Pioneered practical clusterless decoding from multiunit waveform/amplitude marks.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established that unsorted spike marks suffice for accurate decoding, motivating a sorting-free paradigm that the present paper advances with richer features and explicit uncertainty modeling.

prior_works.title: Spike sorting for large, dense electrode arrays
prior_works.authors: Rossant C.; Kadir S. N.; Goodman D. F. M.; et al.
prior_works.role: Introduced template-matching approaches that exploit spatial footprints and per-spike localization on dense probes.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the methodological basis for extracting precise spatial localization features from dense arrays—the key feature family used by the proposed density-based decoder instead of clustering.

prior_works.title: A fully automated approach to spike sorting
prior_works.authors: Chung J. E.; Magland J. F.; Barnett A. H.; et al.
prior_works.role: Automated spike sorting (JRCLUST) emphasizing per-spike spatial localization and drift correction on high-density probes.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplied algorithms for robust spike localization that the paper leverages as input features for mixture-based decoding without committing to hard cluster assignments.

prior_works.title: Fully integrated silicon probes for high-density recording of neural activity (Neuropixels)
prior_works.authors: Jun J. J.; Steinmetz N. A.; Siegle J. H.; et al.
prior_works.role: Hardware enabling dense, high-SNR recordings with stable spatial spike footprints across channels.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Made feasible the extraction of informative localization-based spike features at scale, an essential prerequisite for the paper’s sorting-free, density-based decoding strategy.

prior_works.title: Accurate estimation of neural population dynamics without spike sorting
prior_works.authors: Trautmann E. M.; Stavisky S. D.; Lahiri S.; et al.
prior_works.role: Demonstrated that skipping spike sorting can match or exceed performance for decoding and latent dynamics estimation.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Empirically validated the premise that sorting is unnecessary for high-quality decoding, motivating the paper’s explicit probabilistic treatment of assignment uncertainty via density models.

prior_works.title: YASS: Yet Another Spike Sorter
prior_works.authors: Lee J. H.; Carlson D. E.; Kohn A.; Leslie C. S.; Paninski L.
prior_works.role: Deep-learning-based spike sorting that emphasizes accurate spike detection and spatial localization on dense arrays.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided concrete techniques for precise spike localization that the current work repurposes as rich unsorted features for mixture-based decoding.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—bypassing spike sorting by directly modeling the density of rich, unsorted spike features with a mixture-of-Gaussians to decode behavior—sits at the intersection of clusterless decoding theory and dense-probe spike localization. Early clusterless work (Kloosterman et al., 2014) showed that multiunit marks (e.g., waveform amplitudes) can support accurate Bayesian decoding without assigning spikes to neurons, establishing the conceptual foundation that spike sorting is not strictly necessary. Deng et al. (2015) formalized this idea with a marked point-process filter that explicitly models mark distributions—often with Gaussian mixtures—providing the methodological template for representing spike-identity uncertainty via generative density models. 
Concurrently, dense-probe recording and sorting advances made per-spike spatial localization feasible and reliable: Rossant et al. (2016) and Chung et al. (2017) developed template-based and automated pipelines that extract spatial footprints and locations, while Neuropixels hardware (Jun et al., 2017) enabled high-SNR, high-channel-count recordings where such localization features are richly informative. YASS (Lee et al., 2017) further sharpened localization accuracy using modern learning-based detection. 
Finally, Trautmann et al. (2019) provided strong empirical evidence that spike sorting can be dispensed with for decoding and latent-dynamics estimation, motivating a principled alternative. The present paper unifies these lines: it leverages dense-probe spike localization as high-value marks and adopts mixture-based density models to encode assignment uncertainty directly in the decoder, yielding a spike-sorting-free approach tailored to modern high-density recordings and BCI settings.
